title-group.article-title: The Importance of Definition in Diagnosing Obesity
title-group.subtitle: A Review of Studies of Children in China

contrib.degrees: MBBS, MPH, PhD, FRACGP, FAFOM, FAFPHM

article-meta.aff: 2Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, China

author-notes.corresp: Colin Binns, School of Public Health and Curtin Health Innovation Research Institute, Curtin University, GPO Box U1987, Perth 6845, Western Australia, Australia Email: c.binns@curtin.edu.au

permissions.copyright-holder: Asia-Pacific Academic Consortium for Public Health

abstract.p: The prevalence of childhood overweight and obesity in China has increased in recent decades. However, studies reported from China use several different definitions and growth references, making it difficult to compare the rates of obesity from different regions. It also makes it difficult to establish the extent of secular trends in obesity and to make international comparisons. This article reviews the definitions of childhood obesity used in Chinese studies published over the past 10 years. The majority (79%) of the Chinese studies used a definition of >120% of the mean value of the National Center for Health Statistics reference population to diagnose childhood obesity. Only 7 studies (9%) conducted in China measured childhood obesity using age-specific and sex-specific body mass index (BMI) cutoffs, including International Obesity Task Force cutoffs, Centers for Disease Control 2000 and World Health Organization 2006 BMI curves, and Chinese BMI curves. It is important that a consistent and applicable definition is used and all studies accurately define the obesity with growth reference, cutoff criteria, sample selection, and age distribution. The use of sex-specific and age-specific BMI cutoffs should be considered when undertaking future studies of obesity in Chinese children.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Overweight and obesity in children is a growing problem worldwide, including the Asia Pacific region.1 Once considered to have one of the leanest populations,2,3 China is fast catching up with the West in the prevalence of overweight and obesity.4,5 However, the absence of agreement on the definitions to be used in classifying obesity in China has meant that the prevalence and trends of obesity have not been accurately documented for Chinese children. National and local surveys often give different rates of obesity, and surveys from different parts of China cannot be compared or combined within China or internationally because of the different diagnostic criteria used.

Despite these difficulties with classifying obesity, there is little doubt that childhood obesity in China is increasing. A national epidemiological survey of childhood obesity in 2006 in China found that the prevalence of overweight and obesity in 0- to 6-year-old urban children was 19.8% and 7.2%, respectively, which was 4.7 and 3.6 times higher than that of 1996, respectively.6 The definition of overweight/obesity used was more than 1 Z-score and 2 Z-scores above the mean reference value of weight for height made by World Health Organization (WHO).6 A further epidemiological survey of obesity rates in children of same age group in 9 cities of China, using cutoff points of >10% of median National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS)/WHO reference population as overweight and >20% as obesity gave rates of 6.25% and 3.19%, respectively.7

Obesity is defined as an excess of body fat mass and ideally a definition based on percentage of body fat would be used, but this is impracticable for epidemiological use.8 Body mass index (BMI; in kg/m2) is widely accepted as a standard for the assessment of obesity in adults as it generally reflects body fat.9,10 In children, dynamic growth makes the choice of definitions more complex.

Weight-for-height measurements using the NCHS/Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)/WHO growth charts as reference have been commonly used to diagnose childhood overweight and obesity.11 These have been used in 3 different ways. First is a set percentage above the median weight-for-height in the individual’s age and sex group, with most commonly a cutoff point of >120%.9,11-14 The second approach is to select specific percentiles with the 85th percentile commonly used as the cutoff point for overweight and the 97th percentile for obesity.12 As a further alternative, the Z (or standard deviation) score is used; a Z score of plus 2 or more (ie, 2 standard deviations above the median) is usually taken to indicate obesity.11,12

In recent years, BMI has been increasingly used to classify weight status in children.15,16 Three data sets are used internationally to define overweight and obesity in children in terms of BMI: US CDC 2000 standard,17 the International Obesity Task Force (IOTF)8 reference, and the WHO 2006 standard.18 The method used by the IOTF has the potential advantage that it can be adjusted to reflect different BMI cutoff levels recommended for adults of Asian ethnic groups.

Because the use of different criteria results in differing reports of prevalence rates, it is important to reach a consensus on diagnostic criteria.19,20 The objective of this article is to review the definitions used in published surveys of obesity in Chinese children over the past 10 years.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: A search of the following databases was undertaken: PubMed, Web of Knowledge, ScienceDirect, CNKI (China National Knowledge Infrastructure), and Wangfang Data. The search was limited to English and Chinese articles published between 2001 and 2010 using the search strategy outlined in Box 1. This yielded 2907 abstracts, which were screened for possible inclusion in the review. Studies that did not include preschool children (under age 7) were excluded. Also, studies were excluded that were designed for children with special needs (such as diabetes, cardiovascular, eating disorders, or autism); that did not include both girls and boys; those aimed exclusively at plasma lipids, blood pressure, fat intake, nutritional status, gene, breastfeeding interventions, or interventions treating clinical malnutrition, deficiency, or toxicity; and those without any measurements of overweight or obesity. The review was restricted to the mainland provinces and autonomous regions of the People’s Republic of China, and data from regions and provinces of Macau, Hong Kong, and Taiwan were not included. This resulted in 75 full text articles that included anthropometric measures and screening criterion for overweight or obesity. The reference lists of these articles were scanned for further publications. Each article was tabulated under the year of survey, measured age group, national or local study, sample size, definition/classification of childhood obesity, reference population, and prevalence.

boxed-text.label: Box 1.
boxed-text.title: Search Terms and Strategy
boxed-text.p: Combined with Obesity （肥胖 ）or Overweight (超重)
Not: Adult (成人) OR Female (女性) OR Male (男性) OR Disease (疾病) OR Syndrome (症状/综合症) OR Diabetes (糖尿病) OR Patient (病人) OR Blood (血) OR Gene (基因) OR Cardio (心) OR Intervention (干预)

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The full texts of more than 100 studies conducted in China were retrieved, but only 75 included a measurement of obesity in children aged less than 7 years (Table 1). Studies reporting obesity in preschool children included 67 cross-sectional, 5 quasi-experimental, and 3 longitudinal studies. Anthropometric measurements were reported in 67 studies, 6 analyzed data collected from secondary sources, and 2 of them used weight and height reported by parents. The stated objectives were to report rates of childhood obesity, to examine factors that influenced rates of obesity, or to track trends in obesity rates.

The definition of childhood obesity used in each of the 75 studies was recorded. In 59 of the studies, the definition was >120% of the median weight-for-height of the reference population. Thirty-seven of the studies subdivided obesity into “light obesity” when weight-for-height was >120% to 130%, “moderate obesity” when ≥130% to 150%, and “severe obesity” when ≥150% of the median weight-for-height of the reference population. In 25 of the studies overweight was defined as exceeding 110% of the median weight-for-height of the reference population. In 1 study overweight was defined as exceeding 115% of the median weight-for-height.21

caption.p: Indexes and Cutoff Points Used in Chinese Studies to Define Child Obesity

2002: 6.01, old town areas; 3.87, new town areas
Obesity I: 2.7 (M, 3.2; F, 2.2); obesity II: 5.3 (M, 7.0; F, 3.4)

sec.p: Most studies used the NCHS/CDC reference population to define child obesity. One study used WHO 2006 growth charts as reference for children aged less than 6 years, but it also used NCHS/CDC reference population for children aged 6 to 7 years.22 Only 1 study used a Chinese reference population to classify obesity.23 Three studies did not indicate the growth reference that was used.

A further 5 studies classified obesity as exceeding the NCHS/WHO median weight-for-height plus 2 Z-score, including 1 article that used 20% over median weight-for-height definition as well.24 Three articles referred to normalized NCHS growth curves recommended by the WHO,6,24,25 and 2 studies referred to the WHO 2006 growth charts.26,27

After 2004, some Chinese researchers reported the use of BMI to diagnose obesity in children, in 11 of the 75 studies reviewed. Four studies defined obesity in preschool children as BMI more than 20, 24, 25, or 28 kg/m2.28-31 In a study on risk factors of child obesity from the Tianjin area, results were given for 2 different obesity cutoff points, and children with BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2 and BMI ≥ 24 kg/m2 were considered obese.28 Another study on obesity and risk factors for children aged 2 to 12 years diagnosed obesity using a BMI ≥ 20 kg/m2 in children aged 2 to 5 years and BMI ≥ 21 kg/m2 in children aged 6 to 12 years.29 In a study of children aged less than 7 years, BMI between 18 and 20 kg/m2 was considered overweight, between 20 and 22 kg/m2 was considered as light obesity, between 22 and 25 kg/m2 was considered as moderate obesity, and more than 25 kg/m2 was considered as severe obesity.30 In 2006, Liu et al investigated children aged 3 to 16 years in Chongqing and defined obesity as BMI more than 28 kg/m2.31 No sources of the definition were indicated in these studies.
Three studies used the IOTF BMI criteria for diagnosis,32-35 and in 1 study children were also classified using the CDC 2000 BMI curves.32

A further 4 studies defined child overweight and obesity based on BMI, with the cutoff point set at the 85th and 95th percentiles. Two studies used the WHO 2006 BMI growth curves as reference.36 One study was based on the Chinese children’s BMI curves to diagnose obesity,37 and one did not specify the reference population.38

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this review of Chinese childhood obesity studies over the past 10 years, only 9% of the studies measured childhood obesity using age-specific and sex-specific BMI cutoffs. The majority (84%) of Chinese studies used weight-for-height to diagnose childhood overweight and obesity: 79% used a cutoff point of >120% of the standard (median) value of the reference population and 7% used 2 Z scores above the mean to indicate obesity, including 1 study that used both criteria.

sec.title: Prevalence of Childhood Obesity in China
sec.p: The prevalence of childhood obesity varies from different areas in studies using the same cutoff point of >120% of the median value of the reference population. In 1986, a national survey found that the prevalence of obesity in Chinese children aged less than 7 years was 0.91%, increasing to 1.76% in 1996.39 The highest rate from studies undertaken in 1990 to 2000 was 12.1%, in Shanghai in infants less than 18 months old.40 The lowest rate during this period was 2.3% in children aged less than 7 years, reported from Xi’an.41 In 2000, from the same age group of 3- to 7-year-old children, the prevalence of obesity was 3.9% in Chaoyang, Liaoning province,42 and 7.06% in Beijing.43

From 2001 to 2005, the lowest prevalence reported was 1.6% by an article published in 2002 from Ji’nan in children aged 2 to 7 years.44 The highest prevalence was 8% reported in Xinjiang province in 2001, a study on 3- to 12-year-old children (n = 1815).45 A 15.5% rate of obesity was reported in a further study of children aged 3 to 7 years (n = 2367) from Xinjiang province.46 Han children had a higher rate of obesity than children from the Uyghur ethnic group (18.1% compared with 9.3%).46 Except for Xinjiang province, the highest prevalence was 9.1% found in children aged less than 5 years in Shandong province in 2004, with a sample size of 9590.47

Between 2006 and 2010, the lowest reported obesity prevalence was 1.6% from Kunming (n = 11 172).48 The highest rate was 18.7% in 2006 in Tangshan city (n = 651) and 7.6% in children aged less than 7 years in 2008 in Dalian (n = 10 017).22,49

In studies using a cutoff of +2 Z scores the lowest rate was 3.7% in children aged less than 7 years in Shandong province (n = 3569), 5.2% in the city and 1.8% in rural areas.25 The highest rate was 9.3% in Changchun, reported by a survey conducted in 2007 with a sample size of 4468.27

Using a definition of >120% of the median value of the reference population results in a lower prevalence of child obesity than using a cutoff of >2 Z scores. Comparing the different growth references in use show the extent that results will vary depending on the age of the sample and the reference used.
Since none of the references have percentile curves that are parallel to each other, the proportion classified as obese will vary with the age distribution of the sample.

Using 95th percentile of BMI curve by sex gave a higher prevalence than using the IOTF BMI cutoff to classify child obesity. The lowest prevalence in studies using BMI reference to define child obesity was 1.01% from a national study in 2000 using the IOTF BMI cutoffs to define childhood obesity.33 A further 2 studies using same definition found that in Chongqing (n = 23 292) and Beijing (n = 21 198) the prevalence of obesity in 2- to 18-year-old children was 3.72% and 5.6%, respectively.32,34 However, when using the criterion of the CDC 2000 growth reference, the prevalence in Beijing was 9.0%.32 Mi et al also compared the rates in younger children aged 2 to 6 years using the CDC 2000 criterion (6.8%) and the IOTF criterion (3.5%).32

CDC cutoff points gave higher prevalence rates for both overweight and obesity. This result is consistent with other reports that compared estimates of overweight and obesity in children and adolescents with the CDC and IOTF references.19,50,51 Additionally, the study of Kain et al on 6-year-old Chilean children reported that the overall prevalence of obesity to be halved when using the IOTF cutoff point compared with the CDC’s reference standard.52 As seen repeatedly, the various definitions do not give the same results.

Very few studies in China used the WHO BMI reference. A longitudinal study of 15 852 children aged 3 to 6 years in Tianjin in 2005 found a prevalence of 8.0% using the WHO 2006 BMI curve.36 A study using the same criterion in Ningbo city in 2007 (n = 2220) in 3- to 7-year-old children reported 7.9% obesity.53 Four studies used 5 different BMI values to determine child obesity. A BMI of 25 kg/m2 is recognized internationally as the definition of adult overweight while 30 kg/m2 is recognized as obesity.54 However, in growing children body fat and muscle mass varies with age and sex.8,55 Therefore, BMI is meaningful only when it is plotted correctly on age-specific and sex-specific BMI percentile charts.

A study from the Tianjin area of 9908 children aged 2 to 16 years found a prevalence of 7.4% and 9.4% with BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2 and BMI ≥ 24 kg/m2 as criteria, respectively.28 A study in 2003 in Zengcheng city of 2- to 6-year-old children found an obesity prevalence of 5.5% using BMI ≥ 20 kg/m2 as the criterion.29 In Tianjin, a study of 1.5- to 6-year-old children found 3.8% (confidence interval = 3.4% to 4.2%) obesity using the same definition of childhood obesity: BMI ≥ 20 kg/m2.30

A BMI of 28 kg/m2 was used as definition of obesity for children aged 3 to 16 years in a study from Chongqing.31 This is a high value for defining obesity in preschool children compare with 19.57 kg/m2 for 3-year-old males and 19.36 kg/m2 for 3-year-old females in the IOTF cutoff sets.8 The study reported a very high prevalence of 12.59% of obesity in children aged 3 to 16 years in Chongqing.31

In this review, we have only discussed the criteria used to define obesity. Other limitations of the studies that should be considered included sample selection, measurement protocols, and accuracy and data management, which can also affect the results and comparability between studies.

sec.title: Importance of Measuring Childhood Obesity
sec.p: Monitoring childhood overweight and obesity is important because of associated comorbidities, including respiratory, orthopedic, endocrine, gastrointestinal, and cardiovascular problems56,57 and diabetes mellitus.58,59 It also has a negative effect on the psychological health of children.60-64 Data indicate that a proportion of obese children become obese adults.65,66

At present, there is still no widely agreed standard for classifying overweight and obesity in children and adolescents. The prevalence of childhood obesity can vary considerably when using different definitions or reference populations.19,20

sec.title: Indicators for Measuring Childhood Obesity
sec.p: Reference growth curves were first used to assess undernutrition. After obesity became a more important problem, they have been used in the assessment of overweight in children.67 In the early 1980s, the BMI was validated in children and the first BMI charts were published.68 As in adult obesity, any definition of childhood overweight and obesity needs to be able to define not only the level of body adiposity but also the clinical relevance of this body adiposity.69 Overweight/obesity as measured by BMI during childhood is a strong predictor of obesity and coronary heart disease risk factors in young adulthood.70 BMI is a convenient and appropriate measure for defining and diagnosing childhood obesity and overweight.71,72 BMI can be converted to a centile or Z-score adjusted for age and sex using the US CDC 2000 and WHO 2006 growth reference charts. Changes in adiposity over time can be assessed as a change in BMI, or the proportional (percentage) change in BMI, or the change in BMI Z score or centile.72

sec.title: Reference Data Sets for Defining Childhood Obesity
sec.p: Several reference data sets for BMI in childhood are available, of which 3 are in common use: IOTF, CDC 2000, and WHO 2006 BMI reference. The IOTF differs from the other as it is an extrapolation of adult BMI cutoff points to make them relevant for children and adolescents aged 2 to 18 years.55 The IOTF cutoff values are chosen as the percentiles that matched the adult cutoffs of a BMI of 25 and 30 at age 18 years.

Many researchers have suggested replacing national reference curves with an international standard.71-73 The WHO standard is the most recently developed data set and is being increasingly adopted, and although there are difficulties in infancy, it would seem preferable to a multiplicity of different growth references.74,75

Although no reference has provided risk-based values of BMI used to determine cutoff values, the IOTF reference provides a crude association with ill health later in life, namely, the definition of overweight and obesity at age 18 years.76 As such, the use of the IOTF data sets and cutoffs to screen for body mass status may seem an appropriate option. However, studies in China and other countries have found that the IOTF reference gave lower estimates of obesity for young children than the CDC references.19,32,77

Based on the available data (Table 1), it can be concluded that obesity in children in China has increased above its historical levels. Because consistent criteria for classification have not been used and age-adjusted data are not available, it is impossible to accurately quantify numbers and trends. There is a need for a consistent approach to the measurement of obesity in China.

sec.title: Conclusion and Recommendations
sec.p: This review has shown that the prevalence of childhood overweight and obesity in China has increased in recent years. However, the lack of consistent definitions makes the rates difficult to accurately compare. Using different measuring criteria or samples with different age distributions yielded widely different rates of obesity or overweight. The results indicate clearly that a consistent and applicable standard is needed to allow comparisons between different studies. A low proportion of studies conducted in China in the past 10 years measured childhood obesity with a definition of BMI reference. Studies on childhood obesity in China should consider using the IOTF definition of obesity by using sex and age BMI criteria as an interim measure.

At the moment, the IOTF reference and cutoffs are probably preferable for the identification of overweight and obesity in China because they are based on international data sets and have at least a crude association with health risks later in life. Further research is needed to identify the level of health risks associated with the WHO standard and its cutoffs when used to assess obesity in China. Whatever reference and definition is used, it is essential that these are stated clearly when surveys are published and eventually a national policy should be established.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
